_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies (68.155(a))

MWC, LLC (MWC) is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by MWC's comprehensive accidental release prevention program.  It is MWC'S policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. Unforeseeably, if such releases do occur, our highly trained employees are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. We are also coordinated with the St. Johns Fire Department, who provides our emergency response services.



The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled (?68.155(b))

We have one (1) regulated substance present at our facility. This substance is ammonia (anhydrous). The highest expected inventory of ammonia (anhydrous) at this facility is 65,000 pounds (rounded to two significant digits for reporting purposes).   



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps (?68.155(c))

Our facility has taken the following steps as required by 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA regulations. Our ammonia (anhydrous) process is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.  Our facility is also subject to the EPCRA Section 302 reporting requirements. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our facility. 



Process Safety Information:

Information related to the hazards of the ammonia refrigeration system installed at the facility has been compiled. Prior to conducting the initial and subsequent hazard analysis, the process safety information was reviewed and utilized in identifying and mitigating recognized hazards. The process safety information was also used in the development of the operating procedures.   



Process Hazard Analysis: 

Comprehensive studies are conducted to ensure that hazards associated with our process are identified and c

ontrolled effectively. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is the what-if/checklist. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of every five (5) years. Any findings related to the process hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner. 



Operating Procedures: 

Operating procedures are maintained at the facility. These procedures address the various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process. 



Training: 

A comprehensive training program is in place to ensure that employees operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with those processes. New employees receive basic classroom training in process operations, followed by on-the job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training on operating procedures is provided at least once every three (3) years, and more frequently as needed. 



Mechanical Integrity: 

Documented maintenance checks are conducted on process equipment to ensure proper operation. Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with current training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are given specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. 



Management of Change: 

Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and processes. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other

employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification are promptly made aware of and given training to deal with the modifications. 



Pre-Startup Reviews: 

Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modification of established processes are conducted as a regular practice. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment into operation. 



Compliance Audits: 

Compliance audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation are being implemented. These audits are carried out at least every three (3) years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. 



Incident Investigation: 

Incidents that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance are promptly investigated. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring. All incident reports are retained for a minimum of five (5) years. 



Employee Participation: 

MWC strongly believes that process safety management and accident prevention are a team effort. Company employees are strongly urged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information collected as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP regulation, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. 



Contractors: 

Contractors are utilized to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is completed. MWC has a strict policy of informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the

contractor's work and the process. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency notification and evacuation, should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. 



Five-Year Accident History (?68.155(d))

This is the initial submission of MWC's RMP as it is a new facility.  MWC has not had any reportable accidents or incidents during the past five (5) years. 



Emergency Response Plan (?68.155(e))

This facility is included in the written community emergency response plan. This facility has its own emergency action plan as well. The emergency action plan includes actions to be taken in response to accidental releases of regulated substances as well as procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety (?68.155(f))

This facility has been designed and constructed according to the latest codes and standards to ensure its safe operation.  We will ensure regular reviews of the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system and procedures and continue our notification and evacuation drills and pre-planning with the St. Johns Fire Department.
